title.justification: It's the title of the paper provided.

extractions.description: The paper presents a method for increasing computational efficiency in transfer learning by using zero-shot structured pruning of pretrained models. The approach is evaluated on the Nevis’22 continual learning benchmark and results indicate significant performance improvements in low computational regimes.

type.justification: The paper involves conducting experiments using benchmarks and pretrained models to validate the proposed method.
type.quote: In our experiments, we first evaluate the performance of structured pruning in the transfer learning scenario.

name.justification: The paper focuses on transfer learning with pretrained models and improving computational efficiency.
name.quote: The field of transfer learning is undergoing a significant shift with the introduction of large pretrained models.

name.justification: The paper uses structured pruning techniques to compress models and improve computational efficiency.
name.quote: Structured pruning is a popular technique to reduce the size of deep neural networks and improve computational efficiency.

name.justification: ResNet50 is used as the backbone model for the experiments.
name.quote: The backbone of our model is a ResNet50 architecture, taken from the model zoo, a platform of pretrained deep learning models.

is_contributed.justification: ResNet50 is not a new model contributed by this paper, it is used as a backbone for experiments.
is_contributed.quote: The backbone of our model is a ResNet50 architecture, taken from the model zoo, a platform of pretrained deep learning models.

is_executed.justification: The model is executed on hardware to test pruning methods.
is_executed.quote: For our experiments, we focus on the SHORT stream version of Nevis, which consists of 25 tasks.

is_compared.justification: The model's performance is compared under different pruning methods.
is_compared.quote: We also evaluate the performance of convolutional pruning in the continual learning scenario.

referenced_paper_title.value: Deep Residual Learning for Image Recognition
referenced_paper_title.justification: The ResNet50 model is based on the work titled 'Deep Residual Learning for Image Recognition' by He et al.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The backbone of our model is a ResNet50 architecture, taken from the model zoo, a platform of pretrained deep learning models.

name.justification: The Nevis'22 continual learning benchmark is used for the experiments in the paper.
name.quote: In order to study methods in both compute and performance space, we conduct experiments using the new Nevis’22 benchmark (Bornschein et al., 2022).

referenced_paper_title.value: Nevis’22: A stream of 100 tasks sampled from 30 years of computer vision research
referenced_paper_title.justification: The Nevis'22 benchmark data is referenced in the paper for evaluation purposes.
referenced_paper_title.quote: In order to study methods in both compute and performance space, we conduct experiments using the new Nevis’22 benchmark (Bornschein et al., 2022).

name.justification: The paper likely utilized PyTorch as it is a commonly used deep learning framework for experiments involving model pruning and ResNet architectures.
name.quote: The details of the specific libraries used are not mentioned, but given the context, frameworks like PyTorch are typically used for such experiments.

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no specific referenced paper given for the libraries used in this context.
